regular-body:
inaturalist:

Around 1pm PST yesterday on Tuesday, November 24th, iNaturalist passed the 2 million observations mark!

Its difficult to tell exactly which observation pushed us over the mark. Chances are it was in a bulk upload from the Whio Forever project in New Zealand. But we do know that when Erick Noe Tapia Banda (@momoto-erick) uploaded this beautiful Tropical Kingbird observation from Oaxaca Mexico at 2:59 PM Oaxaca time the count was 1,999,994.

And 25 seconds later when Kim Hyun-tae (@pintail) posted this great photo of an Eastern Spot-billed Duck from South Chungcheong Province, South Korea the count was 2,000,037.

Last year, I blogged about iNaturalistâs one millionth observation, which we reached on November 7th, 2014. While it took ~6.5 years for iNaturalist to reach its first million observations (2,422 days) it took just about a year (382 days) to reach its second. Ken-ichiâs post from last week includes a cool video that shows this increase in the rate of new iNat observations over the history of the site.

As for this most recent million observations over these past 382 day, they came in an average of 2,617 each day or 1 observation every 33 seconds. About 81% are candidates to become research quality observations (meaning they have locations, photos, and are of wild organisms) and so far about 42% have become research quality (meaning they are candidates that also have community consensus around their identifications).

Plants followed by birds and then insects continue to be the taxonomic categories with the most observations. You can see a finer breakdown of the taxonomic categories that observations on iNaturalist fall into in this Sankey diagram:

I hope everyone reading this from the US has a Happy Thanksgiving and that everyone, no matter where you are, gets a chance to get outside and explore the changing seasons!

-Scott
